docs.lead_paragraph: Continuing this week’s series on what Republicans are risking if they punt on a deficit deal, I recommend reading David Leonhardt’s column on tax increases from yesterday’s Times — and particularly the conclusion, in which he points out that however much wonks may love the idea of a comprehensive tax reform that eliminates credits, loopholes and deductions, it’s just as likely that taxes will go up the old-fashioned way:
docs.abstract: Why Republicans might be courting a soak-the-rich future.
docs.snippet: Why Republicans might be courting a soak-the-rich future.

docs.lead_paragraph: Early in my residency, I realized that like Pavlov’s Russian dogs of yore, the other surgeons-in-training and I had developed a conditioned response to our electronic pagers. Our blood would rush and our breath disappear at the sight of one five-digit extension on our beeper’s screen.
docs.abstract: Emergency room overcrowding is a formidable challenge that even one surgeon dedicated to emergency care couldn’t address for his mother.
docs.snippet: Emergency room overcrowding is a formidable challenge that even one surgeon dedicated to emergency care couldn’t address for his mother.

docs.lead_paragraph: Like so many buzz phrases, “green economy” is an expression that is generously tossed around with little regard for its meaning.

headline.main: ‘Green’ Economy Is Real but Needs a Push, Study Suggests

docs.abstract: While green initiatives are driving growth and innovation, market and policy challenges are preventing them from reaching their full potential, a new study suggests.
docs.snippet: While green initiatives are driving growth and innovation, market and policy challenges are preventing them from reaching their full potential, a new study suggests.

docs.lead_paragraph: Barack Obama has often told the story of his mother's deathbed dispute with her insurance company and left the clear impression that the fight was over health benefits for medical expenses.

docs.lead_paragraph: The recently concluded Supreme Court term is not lacking for sober analysis, so I’ll indulge my freedom to take a different approach. This is an annotated scorecard, a personal take on the term based on what jumps out at me as I look back over the past year.
docs.abstract: A review of the just-concluded Supreme Court term.
docs.snippet: A review of the just-concluded Supreme Court term.

docs.lead_paragraph: A common platitude in India is that domestic workers are part of the family, which belies the depressing slew of stories about underpaid or physically abused workers.
